Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Gender Quotas and Women's Political Representation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The past two decades have witnessed unprecedented gains in women's access to elected office. This trend has occurred in all major regions of the world, largely as a result of the adoption of gender quota policies aimed at increasing the number of women selected as political candidates. The recent and global nature of these developments has sparked both scholarly and popular interest. The expanding literature on gender quotas, however, focuses almost exclusively on questions of design, adoption, and numerical impact. Yet, even a cursory look at quota campaigns reveals that these measures are not simply linked to concerns to increase the numbers of women elected. Advocates suggest that such provisions will increase diversity among the types of women elected, raise attention to women?s issues in policy-making processes, change the gendered nature of the public sphere, and inspire female voters to get more politically involved. In contrast, opponents express concerns that quotas will facilitate the election of "unqualified" women, bring women to office with little interest in promoting women's concerns, reinforce stereotypes about women's inferiority as political actors, and deter ordinary women's political participation. Despite their prevalence in quota debates, the empirical validity of these claims has not yet been systematically addressed. By extension, the potential ramifications of quotas for other political processes are not yet well-understood.

Building on my previous work on gender quotas and women's political representation, this study develops and tests a series of hypotheses regarding quota impact via a large-n dataset of quota campaigns and in-depth case studies in three regions of the world: Western Europe, Latin America, and Sub-Saharan Africa. The investigation is organized around three major facets of political representation: descriptive representation, or the basic attributes of those elected; substantive representation, or attention to group interests in policy-making; and symbolic representation, or the cultural meanings and ramifications of the representative process. Placing questions of representation at the center of analysis does not simply offer a chance to determine whether quotas produce the consequences anticipated by supporters or those feared by opponents. It also provides an entry for (1) assessing whether quotas constitute a step forward for democracy and for women, or alternatively, serve to perpetuate existing patterns of domination and inequality, and (2) exploring how these reforms speak to a variety of literatures in political science by investigation how electoral reforms like gender quotas affect trends in candidate recruitment, legislative behavior, and public opinion and mass mobilization.

The project also seeks to have a broader impact through an integrated program of research, educational, and outreach activities. It will produce scholarly publications, as well as seek to incorporate a wide range of participants and communicate the results to an audience of researchers, policy-makers, and advocates through workshops, collaborative research, a project website, and a new international network of scholars and activists. Two major aspirations are (1) to mentor a new generation of researchers at various stages of their professional development, as well as (2) to help actors "on the ground" better understand the positive and negative consequences of gender quotas, with an eye to empowering them with knowledge that can be used to better realize the original aspirations of these reforms. These activities aim to contribute to wider policy debates regarding relationships between quotas, democracy, and women?s empowerment, thereby ensuring the lasting impact of the project beyond the five years of the award while also establishing a solid foundation for a productive and creative scholarly career.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electoral gender quotas have been adopted widely around the world since the mid-1990s, with the aim of increasing the share of women as political candidates and office-holders. A large literature analyzes the adoption, design, and numerical impact of these measures. This project initiated a ‘second generation’ of research on quotas, theorizing and exploring their impact beyond numbers, inspired by competing predictions raised in quota debates regarding their potential effects on women and on society at large. Advocates suggest, for example, that quotas will increase diversity among the types of women elected, raise attention to women’s issues in policy-making processes, change the gendered nature of the public sphere, and inspire female voters to get more politically involved. In contrast, opponents express concerns that quotas will facilitate access for ‘unqualified’ women, bring women to office with little interest in promoting women’s issues, reinforce stereotypes about women’s inferiority as political actors, and deter ordinary women’s political participation.

This project explored these hypotheses by collecting empirical evidence on the impact of quotas in nine countries across three regions: France, Sweden, and the United Kingdom; Argentina, Brazil, and Mexico; and Senegal, South Africa, and Tanzania. Combining home-based research and fieldwork abroad, the project involved conducting more than 350 interviews with former and current members of parliament, cabinet ministers, party activists, women’s groups, judges, academics, and other practitioners, as well as collecting quantitative and qualitative data on legislator backgrounds, parliamentary activities, and legal and social effects associated with quotas. One postdoctoral fellow, seven graduate students, thirteen undergraduate students, and three local scholars provided research and logistical assistance over the course of the award. The project also funded two gatherings. The first was a workshop at the end of the first year of the award, bringing together approximately 20 scholars exploring the broader impact of quotas in a wide range of country cases in May 2011 at Washington University in St. Louis. The second was a major international conference, organized at the end of the final year of the award, with more than 100 scholars, politicians, and policy-makers from all over the world in May 2017 at Rutgers University. Panels were livestreamed via Facebook and viewed more than 13,000 times by audiences across the globe.

The first-year workshop led to the publication of a volume co-edited with Susan Franceschet and Jennifer M. Piscopo, The Impact of Gender Quotas (Oxford University Press, 2012), which has already been deeply influential in setting the research agenda on the impact of quotas beyond numbers. The volume is organized around three facets of representation – descriptive, substantive, and symbolic – and within each section includes case studies from one country each in Western Europe, Latin America, Sub-Saharan Africa, and Asia and the Middle East. Over the course of the award, I published a number of single- and co-authored articles stemming from the research, including pieces in Political Research Quarterly (2012), Perspectives on Politics (2013), Comparative Political Studies (2014), Political Studies (2014), International Political Science Review (2014), International Studies Quarterly (2015), Parliamentary Affairs (2016), Party Politics (2016), Politics, Groups, and Identities (2016), Política y Gobierno (2016), Annual Review of Sociology (2017), Journal of Democracy (2017), and Political Quarterly (2018). I also co-edited two special journal issues, International Political Science Review (2014) and Representation (2018), as well as edited and co-edited two symposia in Politics & Gender (2013 and 2018). The special issue of Representation was subsequently published as an edited volume by Routledge, entitled Gender Quotas and Women’s Representation: New Directions in Research (2015). I have two single-authored book manuscripts in progress, Violence against Women in Politics (Oxford University Press, forthcoming 2020) and Quotas beyond Numbers: Women, Politics, and Empowerment (in development).

I have actively worked to disseminate the findings of the project beyond the academic world. In addition to talks given to university audiences, I have presented my work on quotas to politicians, policy-makers, electoral administrators, and global practitioners in Italy, Chile, Mexico, Brazil, Vietnam, Japan, Norway, Canada, and Australia, as well as during events convened in New York, Washington, and Geneva by UN Women, the National Democratic Institute, USAID, and the Inter-Parliamentary Union. An article that I co-authored with Mary K. Nugent was cited by advocates who lobbied successfully to introduce party quotas in the British Liberal Democrats in 2016. My work on violence against women in politics, which directly grew out of my NSF-funded fieldwork, has influenced the design of practitioner studies on this phenomenon, and concepts that I developed with Juliana Restrepo Sanín appear in only slighted modified form in the Mexican state institutional protocol to address violence against women in politics. Finally, as part of the project I created a Facebook group on Electoral Gender Quotas, bringing together academics and practitioners, which has now grown to more than 500 members worldwide.
